column3: Comment

column16:
Organizing

Coherence
Integrating
Outlining
Parsing
Structuring

column4: Locating knowledge in long-term memory that is consistent with presented material (e.g. Recognize the dates of important events in US. history)
column5: Retrieving relevant knowledge from long-term memory (e.g. Recall the dates of important events in US. history)
column6: Changing from one form of representation (e.g. numerical) to another (e.g. verbal) (e.g. Paraphrase important speeches and documents)
column7: Finding a specific example or illustration of a concept or principle (e.g. Give examples of various artistic painting styles)
column8: Determining that something belongs to a category (e.g. concept or principle) (e.g. Classify observed or described cases of mental disorders)
column9: Abstracting a general theme or major point(s) (e.g. Wirite a short summary of the events portrayed on a videotape)
column10: Drawing a logical conclusion from presented information (e.g. In learning a foreign language, infer grammatical principles from examples)
column11: Detecting correspondences between two ideas, objects, and the like (e.g.,Compare historical events to contemporary situations)
column12: Constructing a cause-and-effect model of a system (e.g. Explain the causes of important 18th-century events in France)
column13: Applying a procedure to a familiar task (e.g. Divide one whole number by another whole number, both with multiple digits)
column14: Applying a procedure to an unfamiliar task (e.g. Use Newton's Second Law in situations in which it is appropriate)
column15: Distinguishing relevant from irrelevant parts or important from unimportant parts of presented material (e.g. Distinguish between relevant and irrelevant numbers in a mathematical word problem)
column16: Determining how elements fit or function within structure (e.g. Structure evidence in a historial description into evidence for and against a particular historical explanation)
column17: Determine a point of view, bias, values, or intent underlying presented material (e.g. Determine the point of view of the author of an essay in terms of his or her political perspective)
column18: Detecting inconsistencies or fallacies within a process or product, determining whether a process or product has internal consistency; detecting the effectiveness of a procedure as it is being implemented (e.g. Determine if a scientist's conclusions follow from observed data)
column19: Detecting inconsistencies between a product and external criteria, determining whether a product has external consistency; detecting the appropriateness of a procedure for a given problem (e.g. Judge which of two methods is the best way to solve a given problem)
column20: Coming up with alternative hypotheses based on criteria (e.g. Generate hypotheses to account for an observed phenomenon)
column21: Devising a procedure for accomplishing some task (e.g. Plan a research paper on a given historical topic)
column22: Inventing a product (e.g. Build habitats for a specific purpose)

Physical props that are shipped with the games to strengthen the game experience.

Presentations of game worlds as entities within these game worlds would perceive them.
That a random distribution is guaranteed to have produced a given distribution at certain specific points in the sequence of randomness produced.
Alternative ways to reach locations in game worlds which may be unexpected to others.

Sets of game elements given to a player to be given to other players.
The freedom to choose between several different actions or choices which all seem meaningful.

Raised areas that provide advantages through overlooking narrow passages.
A surface designed to support gameplay.

Real world trading between players of the game elements used to play a game.
Stories that are based on gameplay events that took place in a specific game instance of a game.
Diegetic objects in game worlds that can be carried or interacted with.
Meeting spaces for players before game instances begin.
Facilitators of game worlds, and of players' interactions with these worlds.

column2: The event which makes a player no long able to participate in the gameplay of a game instance.
The suspense of progress of game time.
Computer or mechanical systems responsible for running individual game instances.
Players are given information about a certain part of the game state or other players through other means than observing a diegetic game element.
Information provided to players that extends beyond the observational abilities provided by simply observing game elements.
A passive player controlled by the game system.

Actions that let players affect how game time progresses in a game.
The goal or phase of learning the layout of a game world, or locating specific parts or objects within it.
Trying to move from one place in a game world to another when the best way is not obviously apparent.
Fictional worlds in which gameplay takes place.
Player constructed systems that provide benefits for the player that constructed it.
Mastery of performing actions and reaching goals in a game.
Records of game state values or events that can be accessed during or after gameplay.

More or less adversary diegetic entities that are indistinguishable from other similar entities.
Relations where each change in effort results in the effect being multiplied by a fixed value.

The exchange of information by word-of-mouth between diegetic characters.
Achievements given by repeatedly performing some action in a game.
The repeating of simple actions many times to collect resources or complete goals.
The goal to hinder other players or game elements from accessing particular gameplay areas or particular game elements.
column3: e.g. the player needs to choose what he guards

column2: Making players perform actions due to a sense of bad conscience.
Achievements given for completing some goal while under some type of optional handicap.
Systems for making gameplay easier or more difficult for certain players in order to even the chances of all players to succeed or win.
column3: can enhance all type of gameplay

column2: Identifiers to recognize players or their efforts in games.
Collection representing players' current resources of a certain type of game elements.
A measure of how much damage or other negative consequences avatars, characters, or units can take before they suffer serious penalties.
Non-player characters that help players.
column3: can greatly enhance every learning game, see coaches

column2: Gameplay situations where players cannot themselves affect their situation.
The goal of moving one or more game elements to a location without directly interacting with them.
column3: can be used to let the player indirectly categorize items, by first showing him what he needs to do and then draft something (a team, a deck...) to complete that challenge

column2: Game designs that require players to contribute with the game elements anew for each game instance.
Places in games that allow people or things to be hidden.
The storing of scores after games have finished so the they can be compared.
column3: can enhance rewards

column2: Closures that occur progressively become more important as the game is played.
column3: can be used to facilitate flow

column2: Gameplay where players take turns using an interface to interact with the game system.
Events that are about to occur and can clearly be observed by players.
Information and access to game actions that are presented in computer games as if they were on a plane in front of the presentation of the game world.
column3: can enhance all type of gameplay

column2: Gameplay spaces that consist of a combination of both a real world space and a virtual or symbolic one.
Game worlds that appear to have more playable areas than they do.
Rewards that do not quantifiably help in completing goals or positively affect game states for players.
The event of abilities improving their efficiency.
column3: can be used as a reward

column2: Parts of game worlds that players can perceive but cannot enter.
Two or more goals that cannot be fulfilled simultaneously due to having end conditions that are mutually exclusive.
column3: can be used to enhance goals

column2: Reward structures that increase the size or quality of the specific rewards as gameplay progress.
column3: can be used to facilitate flow and enhance rewards

column2: Penalties given in games that only directly apply to one of the players.
column3: can be used to enhance penalties

column2: Rewards in a game which are only given to one player.
column3: can be used to enhance rewards

column2: The passing, from a character to another, of information that has, or can have, influence on the gameplay.
The ability of agents to take actions not directly perceived as the consequence of game events.
Tools in game worlds that due to their size or construction are immovable by players.
Subparts of game worlds created specifically for groups of players as these parts are needed.
Goals whose progress or completion can be directly influenced by other players or the game system.
column3: can be used to enhance goals

column2: The situation of having a set of desirable actions or goals where the progress in one makes the others more difficult or impossible.
column3: can be used to enhance goals

column2: Being a player or character within one's same social network as an enemy or competitor.
Game structures that allow players to interrupt their gameplay without disrupting the gameplay for the players.
Actions that can be interrupted before their effects on the game state have been completely taken place.
column3: e.g. enemy actions that need to be interrupted if they represent a certain type of information

column2: The space containing game elements carried by diegetic characters.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Obstacles in game worlds that limit the players' movement, but not vision.
Game actions the result in new players being invited to join the game.
The ability to be immune to attacks or other dangers.
column3: can be used to enhance damage

column2: Events whose effect on the game state cannot be undone.
Replays of kills in games that are shown directly after they occur.
column3: can enhance killing

column2: Reaching and keeping a sought for game state that other players are trying to reach and keep.
column3: can be used to categorize things by shooting at them

column2: Gameplay situations where a player cannot win but can decide which other player should.
Distinct objects in game worlds that help navigation within them.
column3: can enhance any gameplay where the player navigates in an open area

column2: Routes that focus and guide movement in a game.
Gameplay where players or teams are actively trying to eliminate each other to be the last survivor.
The designed support to allow players to join play sessions of a game independently of when other players' play sessions start.
Actions that are performed without any guaranteed, or visible, chance of success.
Games where some consequences from game instances have permanent effects on future game instances.
A level is a part of the game in which all player action takes place until a certain goal has been reached or an end condition has been fulfilled.
The penalty in a game of losing a life.
column3: can enhance negavite actions/effects

column2: The requirement of having direct view from one game element to another.
Roleplaying that is physically enacted.
The number of chances players has before game instances are terminated.
column3: can be used as a reward/punishment mechanism

column2: Gameplay hints presented during loading sequences.
column3: can enhance any type of gameplay

column2: Abilities only available at certain locations in game worlds.
column3: e.g. the ability to view information only in a library

column2: Items, typically randomly generated, found in game worlds that function as rewards.
column3: can be used as a reward/punishment mechanism

column2: The goal of upholding a diegetic commitment to support a person, group, or cause.
The feeling that random effects are not random but favorable to a player.
Cases where players can by luck find correct solutions for problems.
Gameplay time when players are not stressed about performing actions.
column3: e.g. can be used as a time for the player to learn about a topic

column2: Game elements specifically used to drive the narration in games.
Goals that provide players with information and motivation about what challenges should be attempted in a game.
Quests whose completion provides the main winning condition of games.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Controlling the movement of game elements in real-time games.
Games which support hundreds or thousands of players to inhabit the same game world and interact with each others.
Games that make use of other players' game instances to provide input to the game state.
Gameplay where the players interaction with the game state and/or each other is done through a system.
Narration structures in games which allow players or spectators to know more than any individual diegetic person.
Content or artifacts gained during gameplay that are accessible after game instances end.
Gameplay where players gain benefit by remembering facts about the game or game state.
column3: This is the essence of a learning game

column2: The ability of agents in games to show that they can recollect important events that took place during gameplay.
Games based on the effects and outcomes of other games.
Meta Servers are the servers that distribute players and information between game servers of a specific game as well as stores global information about the players.
Postures and gestures that convey gameplay information that can be performed while roleplaying.
Techniques in roleplaying games that allows players to communicate something to each other without having this communicated between their characters.
The phase or phases that are not the first or last in a game instance.
Gameplay where sensors measures how well a player performs actions in the game.
column3: can be used to enhance all types of gameplay

column2: Maps that provide overviews of the game world.
column3: should be used in all games that have any type of exploration to make it more accessible

column2: A small game played through another game.
column3: a great way to incorperate multiple games without the need of coherance

column2: Games that interfere little with players' abilities to social interact with other people while the games are being played.
The possibility for players to take actions that lower the risk of misfortune for them.
Game elements that move in diegetic game world but not by their own agency.
column3: can be used to categorize things by shooting at them

column2: The action of moving game elements in game worlds.
Negative changes in how movement is done.
column3: can enhance movement

column2: Code algorithms that can take over the role of players from repetitious tasks.
Games that have more than one player.
column3: can enhance alot of types of gameplay

column2: The enjoyment of together with other players handling very chaotic or challenging gameplay situations.
Goals that are shared by two or more agents in a game.
column3: can enhance goals with cooperative gameplay

column2: Letting players choose the names of characters or other game elements.
The underlying structures of stories that games contain or can create.
Means of providing players with explicit information about how close they or others were to achieving a goal when they have failed to achieve it.
column3: can be used to motivate the player and good way to facilitate learning

column2: Rule systems that affect the game state to move a specific part of the game state towards a preset value.
column3: can be used to facilitate flow

column2: Games where the time duration of the entire game instance is negotiable.
Support for players to have complete gameplay experiences while having influence over the time need and without negatively affecting other players' gameplay experience.
Support for individual players to be able to decide how long their play sessions should be without negatively affecting the outcome or gameplay for all players.
Other players acknowledged as being allowed to affect ones gameplay.
Abilities gained during gameplay that allows for new actions to be performed.
column3: can be used to facilitate flow

column2: The act of taking loot that one has no proper claim to.
Games where players direct influence on the actual gameplay is non-existent or close to non-existent.
column3: e.g. a game where you program something to play "for you" and you need to use you knowledge so that it succeeds (doing stuff in the correct order or using the correct action)

column2: Player actions that perform no change on the game state.
The providing of bonuses to unselected actions to make them more like to be used in the future.
column3: can enhance actions, see action caps

column2: Story-telling in a game which is not internally consistent.
Communication between players during gameplay which is not framed as communication between agents in the game world.
Parts of the presentation of a game that do not fit its diegesis.
column3: is a very important part of a game and enhances alot of aspekt (althought it can also be a design decision to not have any non-diegetic features to improve immersion)

column2: Resources in games that at least partly do not have physical locations.
Diegetic persons in game worlds that are not controlled by players.
column3: See agents

column2: The designed possibility for people not playing the game to help players.
column3: Very hard to implement, but could be a nice way to enhance gameplay

column2: Resources that do not increase in number during gameplay.
column3: Can be for example used to force the player to use his helps only sparingly because he only has a finite amount

column2: Game elements that hinder players from taking the shortest route between two places in game worlds.
Movement from one part of a game world to another which cannot be reserved or where the return takes a disproportional amount of effort.
The ability of agents to have different narrative arcs between game instances due to the events that took place in the game session.
Die rolls where some results indicate making more die rolls to achieve the final result.
Goals that players do not need to complete to win or finish a game.
Rules of a game that players can choose to use or not.
Differences in abilities of game entities that are in type rather than in value.
column3: Having differentiating abilities to solve different tasks is important for good gameplay

column2: Means of providing players with information about an outcome of an action in addition to the diegetic effect of the action.
column3: can be a great help for non-experienced players

column2: The goal of defeating an opposing force.
The ability of algorithmic agents to seem to strive towards personal goals.
Game elements that when individually lost do not interrupt gameplay, but do so when all or a predefined amount of them are lost.
Groups of characters working together to reach common diegetic goals.
Save files which consist only of a password.
Games that require players to pay in some for to play.
Effects on the game state that are negative to players regarding their position, progress, or abilities.
column3: can be used to penalize the player, e.g. after answering something wrong he can't use an ability for some time

column2: Gameplay where the uncertainty of outcome of actions is due to how well players perform these actions.
Permanent avatar or character deaths.
column3: can be very frustrating and should only be used (in learning games) after very thorough considerations

column2: Changes to game worlds that do not automatically revert.
Game worlds that exist independently of players' game and play sessions.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Gameplay that can co-exist or merge with other activities.
The removal or changing of game elements for a sub group of players of a game instance.
column3: Can be used to implement/enhance quests

column2: Enactment of physical actions in games by players doing the actions themselves.
Navigation through gameplay environments through bodily movement.
Game items that exist in game worlds and can be collected, usually by moving avatars or units so that they are in contacts with the game items.
column3: can either be used as general rewards or to categorize things

column2: Games which make use of presentations inside other presentations.
The ability of players to be able and influence gameplay through gameplay actions or ways of affecting game instances themselves.
Physical material that is handed out to players during gameplay to provide more information about the game world or the current situation.
column3: impossible to implement for a purely digital game

column2: The case where the identity of a player of a game is not known to other players.
Support mechanisms that boost players' abilities to perform gameplay activities.
column3: e.g. can be used to help players (e.g. with aim assist)

column2: Design structures in a game which works towards players having equal chances of succeeding with actions in a game or with winning the game.
Characters in games that are under players' direct control or represent the players role in the gameplay.
Game Elements created by players to be used in a game.
The forced endings of players' game sessions before game instances are finished.
The extra-game action of removing a player from game instances.
The removal of players from active gameplay through active actions.
Players' abilities to perform physical activities are used to determine the outcome of a game.
The limit on what will happen in future gameplay due to not knowing how other players will act.
Game rules that depend on players being physically close to artifacts.
column3: can be used as controllers or location-fixed abilities

column2: Game rules that depend on players being physically close to avatars.
column3: can be used as controllers or location-fixed abilities

column2: Characters whose creation players' have had some influence over.
Goals and subgoals that players can create or customize within a game.
Game rules that depend on players being physically close to places.
column3: can be used as controllers or location-fixed abilities

column2: The possibility for players to plan how game state values and entities should be able to develop.
Game rules that depend on players being physically close to other players.
column3: can be used as controllers or location-fixed abilities

column2: Games that ensure that what a player's character knows about the game world is the same as what the player knows.
Outcomes of player actions that depends both on both player and character characteristics.
column3: This is very hard to do in a learning game but can be very rewarding if it works

column2: Game systems where a player's actions can be initiated by either that player or the system, or where the execution of the actions are performed together.
Gameplay directed at making one's own character lose to provide enjoyable for oneself.
Game actions that point players towards important aspects of game worlds, or entities within them.
Polyathlons are games or tournaments consisting of several different challenges where each challenge requires a different skill set.
Rule systems that affect the game state so that future similar affects will have greater impact on the game state.
column3: Positive feedback loops are a great way to enforce player behaviour and can enhance any type of gameplay

column2: That players have the possibility to not reveal their identities while playing a game.
The ability for players to leave gameplay or surrender to other players without negatively affecting the gameplay for all other players of a game instance.
The management of game resources for its own sake.
Game elements that provide instant benefits or advantages when collected.
column3: can be used as a reward

column2: Creation of decks of cards by players for their own use before gameplay starts.
Goals of the game that have been predefined by designers before gameplay begins.
Narration structures whose order presentation in a game exists before game instances begin.
The possibility to predict how game states will change due to actions or events.
column3: can enhance delayed effects

column2: Games where the players can perceive who is very likely to win given the current gameplay circumstances.
Goals where the objective is to prevent a completion of another goal.
column3: can be used to enhance multiplayer gameplay by giving the players the ability to mess with the opponents progress

column2: Parts of the game space that only a single player can manipulate directly.
Abilities that let agents perform actions not readily available to others.
column3: see assymetric gameplay

column2: Being able to do a form of movement that others cannot.
column3: see assymetric gameplay

column2: Game worlds created through algorithms.
column3: can be a great way to enhance gameplay by keeping it fresh and different each time, can even be the basis of gameplay

column2: Information about players' current progress towards closures in addition to the configuration of game elements involved.
Prompts players can use while roleplaying to communicate intentions about changing scenes without breaking the diegesis.
Diegetic elements of game worlds that have no gameplay enabled through them.
Statistics about players that are easily accessible to others.
The possibility for players to spend real world currency to gain in-game advantages.
Activities that can primarily be solved through reasoning.
column3:
Puzzles can be used in a variety of ways:
A simple way is to hide the correct solution (e.g. the combination for a door) behind a riddle that can only be solved by having some sort of knowledge
They can also be unsolvable before applying some sort of process to elements of it

column2: Gameplay where game systems, rather than other players, provide challenges to players.
Gameplay where players as individuals are in active conflict with each other.
Goals within games with rewards associated to their completion.
Navigational structures that make returning from a certain position to a part of the game world much easier than reach it.
Sequences of interface actions given by games that players need to perform at once.
Ways for players to move between different places in a game world without visiting the intermittent places.
column3: can enhance games with long travel distances

column2: Collections of questions asked to players as part of gameplay.
column3: One of the easiest ways to test any kind of knowledge

column2: Cryptic invitations to start playing specific game instances.
Gameplay goals that need to be worked against under pressure, often but not necessarily in competition against others.
column3: can be used to enhance goals

column2: Quitting a game instance due to anger or frustration without regards to how this will affect gameplay for others.
Effects or events in the game cannot be exactly predicted.

column1: Real Life Activities Affect Game State
column2: Gameplay where real world activities done for other purposes than playing the game provide input to the game state.
Games where the specifics of physical space that constitutes the gameplay space affects the gameplay.
Games where players can make use of specific real world knowledge to their advantage.
column3: This should be the goal of every learning game

column2: The progression of game time during play is tied to the progress of real time.
Game worlds whose fundamental structures can change during gameplay or between game instances.
Patrolling game world areas to detect changes.
Objects or information designed to mislead or distract players.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Resources in games that are created simply by the passing of game time.
Resources which in some manner are replenished during gameplay.
Combos that consist of performing the same kind of action repeatedly a certain number of times within a certain time limit.
Rules that make games end in draws if players make position or game states repeat themselves in a game instance.
Gameplay that requires the same type of actions or choice repeatedly to a player.
The level to which a game provides new challenges, learning opportunities, or experiences when played again.
Stored recordings of gameplay.
The goal of freeing someone or something that is guarded or otherwise not free to move by its own will.
column3: e.g. rescue the correct person/item

column2: Members of teams that are not active in the gameplay due to a limit on how many can be active at once.
Limits on numbers of resources allowed to be used or stored.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Places in game world that contain resources.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Abstract or diegetic places where resources can be found or acquired.
Game elements that are used by players to enable actions in a game.
Rules regarding how to handle situations where players have not followed the rules of trick taking.
Rewards that are placed within game environments without being diegetically present.
Things received in games which are perceived as positive.
column3: a great way to enforce learning by giving rewards when the correct knowledge is shown

column2: An activity requiring players to time their actions in relation to a rhythm.
column3: e.g. knowledge can be encoded in a certain rythm that the player needs to replicate to show that he has that knowledge

column2: Physical robots created or appropriated to take part as players of a game.
The fulfillment experienced when being good at your assigned or implicit role in a group, or the frustration experienced when you have fulfilled your role, but the group still fails
Selecting what gameplay abilities one will have by choosing from a limit number of roles.
Gameplay where players take on the goals and behaviors of fictional agents.
Locations in game worlds where game elements are safe from harmful game events.
Cheating which either is supported by the game design or is seen as acceptable to a certain degree by other players.
Files that contain information to recreate game states.
Specific points in game worlds, or between levels, where players can save the game state.
Overuse of saving and loading possibilities in games that replay taking on gameplay challenges.
The actions of saving and loading game states to help get the game state one wishes.
A gameplay period diegetically localized in time and space.
A track to show players' scores.
Numerical values used in games to determine winners.
column3: can be used as a reward

column2: Moving in a game world to gain information about threats while trying to not be observed.
Preset sequences of events that take place while players can still affect gameplay.
Games where explicit knowledge of the coverage areas of underlying sensing technologies provide gameplay advantages.
Screens that provide actions and information to players which complement the main interface in a game.
Areas of game worlds that are not easily noticed.
Goals that players have which at least some other players do not have knowledge about.
Resources that at least one players is unaware of concerning existence or specific details.
Ways of gaining points in a game which is not revealed until used or until the final scoring phase of the game.
Goals which players can choose a subset to strive towards.
Games that require that the people involved in the gameplay ensure that the rules are being followed and require that these people perform any necessary bookkeeping actions.
Games where variations in players' physical locations are part of the gameplay but where the current locations are reported to the game by the players.
Location in game worlds where players can on their own do transactions or receive services.
Algorithmic Agents that consistently react appropriate to events concerning it or to its internal states.
Penalties that make players have to redo actions or routes in a game.
Groups of game elements that together provide more benefits than they do individually.
Penalties shared between some or all players for a failure to meet a requirement in a game.
Resources which several players have access to during a game instance, either continuously or at varying times.
Forced sharing of rewards between players.
Game worlds that become smaller as gameplay progresses.
Modification to game items to provide uses that are more specialized.
Quests which are optional to a game's main quest structure.
Games where each game instance only there is only supports one player.
Representation of how likely diegetic agents are to succeed with a type of activity that can be improved through experience.
column3: see abilities

column2: Locations in game worlds suited for snipers.
Games that through their design easily can be modified for varying social contexts.
Choices players need to make that either set their own individual gains against each others or against the gains of a social group they belong to.
Rewards provided by a game that can help players' social regard rather than giving direct in-game benefits.
Roles people can receive or take in relation to each other based on gameplay features.
Gameplay where players social abilities affect how well they succeed with their actions.
Spaces for game item upgrades.
Uncertainty in a game which stems from not being aware of an existent solution to a challenge.
Locations in game worlds where avatars, units, or enemies appear.
The event of avatars, units, or other game elements entering game worlds.
The enjoyment to be had when failing in a spectacular way in a game.
People, possibly former, current, or future players, who observe the actions that players do in a game without being able to affect the game themselves.
Taking actions to end a game as quickly as possible when one believes oneself to be leading.
The goal of completing a game or a part of a game where time is the most essential measure of success.
Divisions of a screen space which are used to display continuously updated views of game environments.
Manipulating the randomness of drawing stacks by ensure the presence of certain elements in certain parts of the stacks.
The initial phase in games with clear gameplay phases.
The inescapable depletion of a resource as gameplay progresses.
The goal to move and perform actions while remaining undetected.
column3: e.g. use the correct spots to hide from enemies, because the wrong ones disappear after a timelimit (or only look like hiding spots until the enemy is nearby)

column2: Gameplay structures that encourage players to plan future actions in the game.
The act of telling stories within the game.
column3: a great way to introduce any kind of knowledge, be careful not to overuse this

column2: Knowledge based on game elements, rules, possible actions, or evaluation functions of games without regards to specific game states.
Areas in game worlds that are advantageous to control or have access to.
Planning based solely on knowledge of game rules and the abilities of other players.
Game locations that are good positions when defending against enemies.
Enactment where one type of action represents another action.
Descriptions of events that have taken place in the game before or after actual gameplay.
Goals whose primary effect is to help players achieve other goals of a game.
Attacks that come unexpected to the target of those attacks.
The act of a player to abandon a game instance in acknowledgment of being beat.
The goal of trying to avoid having game elements being eliminated, killed, or otherwise removed from gameplay.
Rewards consisting of replenishing resources that are constantly consumed.
Game elements that players can use to activate events or actions in game worlds.
Gameplay relations between players that make successes and failure of one player affect another similarly, and vice versa.
Goals that from a systemic perspective are symmetric to each other.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Games in which all players' game and play sessions overlap with each other in time.
Planning based on what one knows of the current game state.
The fulfilment experienced when being part of and accomplishing something as a group
The state that competing teams have somewhat equal chances of succeeding with actions in a game or winning a game.
Sets of actions performed by several different players that trigger additional effects than those that occur due to the individual actions.
Changes over time to teams due to changes in the game state or player skills.
The goal of eliminating a whole team from gameplay.
Discovering and deciding on a team strategy, often based upon using synergies.
Agents or game elements that use their actions to work towards the same common goal or goals.
That the sequence of gameplay events that make up game instances match a sequence of diegetic events in the game world in which they are initiated.
Abilities only available for limited periods of game time.
column3: e.g. the ability to get help while in a startingarea but not later

column2: The feeling of caring about the outcome of actions or events in a game without having full control over them.
Pieces of game worlds that are owned by agents of those worlds.
Achievements given simply by having tested some action in the game.
That the characters and objects depicted in a game world are thematically consistent, as is their behavior.
Presentations of game worlds focused upon specific entities in those game worlds and change in relation to the entities' movement and not from the perception of a diegetic agent.
Real-time games which have sufficiently long intervals between update phases to let players make use of these for planning or choosing when to play.
Rules for how to make distinctions in what would else be tied results.
Two or more results calculated during game that are treated as equal, and produce equal consequences for those with the results.
Games where players can belong to different tiers in regards to their expected involvement in the gameplay.
The act of placing game elements when their spatial relation to other such game elements affects gameplay.
column3: e.g. lay the correct tiles into the correct spots

column2: Game elements used to distribute resources, often with different characteristics, without necessarily revealing the distribution.
Games that by their design limit the time of any given game instance.
An amount of time, either game time or real time, used in determining if players complete an action, reach a goal, stay in a certain mode of play, or finish a game session.
That gameplay imposes a sense of need for complete actions or goals quickly.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Using tokens to select future actions to be performed.
Game elements used to provide actions, or make them easier to perform, in game worlds.
column3: can either be used as a reward or as a help with limited uses

column2: Additional information presented when players have focused on a game element.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Game elements, or distinct parts of game worlds, that guide players to locations in the environment that influence gameplay.
Gameplay situations where players must choose between several different options and compare values against each other.
The one-sentence "definition" that should be in italics.
Game items that are possible to transfer between avatars or characters.
A route in a game world that players need to traverse to get to certain locations.
Game Elements or game events that kill or damage avatars and units.
The goal to try to move a game element from one position in a game world to another position.
column3: e.g. the player can choose between multiple paths that he needs to traverse and he only knows which one is the correct way by his knowledge. This can be a great way to incorperate gameplay with learning

column2: Gameplay solutions that can be found by going through all possible solutions.
A play of cards or tiles by several players which is won by one of them.
column3: e.g. custom cards with custom rules on what trumps what (which is only possible to know if the player has the right knowledge)

column2: A suit of card that beat other suits in trick taking.
Letting one player do some action or actions before letting other players act.
A neighbor controlled by the game to help players learn the game.
Games where the gameplay is clearly divided into clearly defined parts where players can plan and select actions
The immediate ending of one player's turn due to a game event to start another player's turn.
Games where teams compete against teams.
Gameplay which is possible at most times and in most locations without requiring significant adjustments to these locations.
Events that cannot be affected by player actions.
The case when a player cannot be certain on the reliability of information he or she has.
The characteristic of a game that it is difficult to reliably determine what the final outcome of a game instance will be before gameplay begins.

Disposable game elements under the control of the game system or players that are either interacted with on a group level or have no individual distinguishing features from a set of other game elements.
Goals initially, or currently, unknown to the players that have them.
The act of getting access to additional abilities or game-related content.
The ability of agents to make actions that are unexpected.
Gameplay where the beginning and end of different players' game sessions are not aligned.
Game states from which no actions or events in a game instance can let a player win.
Games that do not have any winning conditions.
Modifications to game items to make them more effective.
The gameplay experience of that one's efforts during gameplay have value.
Game mechanics to simulate differences in the difficulty to hit what one aims at.
Variation in gameplay for a game, either within a single play session or between different play sessions.
Games where the rules governing gameplay change over time from within a closed set of rules.
Turn taking sequences that change, or can be changed, during gameplay.
Gameplay areas created for vehicular movement.
Game elements that allows for faster movement, or different types of movement, than that normally available.
Different ways of presenting the same views in a game world.
Temporary being in a part of a game world that is controlled by another player.
Weaknesses that can be exploited by others.
column3: see achilles heel

column2: Exercises before gameplay begins that help players prepare for enactment and roleplaying.
Links between physically non-adjacent locations in game world to make them spatial neighbors.
Timed attacks by large numbers of identical enemies.
Game elements used as tools to cause death and destruction in game worlds.
Games where the winner(s) are determined after gameplay ends.
Games which are one by achieving a required game state which ends gameplay.
Workshop techniques used before games to create the diegesis or prepare for playing.
Games where humans have no direct choices during the gameplay.
column3: e.g. a game where the player needs to configure the starting parameters in a way that allows his character to win in the end

column2: The ability of game elements to affect the functionality of those adjacent to them.
